awd_titl_txt: Central Engine Models for Extreme Core-Collapse Supernovae and Long Gamma-Ray Bursts
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a comprehensive theoretical investigation into core collapse and the resulting supernovae explosions of massive stars.  The project will focus on full-star simulations in three dimensions of compact progenitors of certain classes of supernovae and long gamma-ray bursts.  The goals of the project are (1) to explore the physical conditions and processes that distinguish between various outcomes of the explosion and to understand which situations produce gamma-ray bursts; (2) to track neutrino-driven and magnetorotational explosions through compact progenitors and make predictions about explosive yield of various nuclei, mixing of ejecta, and explosion morphologies that can be compared with electromagnetic observations; and (3) to provide predictions for the gravitational wave and neutrino signatures of extreme core collapse supernovae and long gamma bursts.

Gamma-ray bursts are probably the most energetic events in the universe, and the physics involved is still not well understood.  The project is expected to release its codes and simulations to the astrophysics community, and will also involve the training of graduate students in numerical astrophysics.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to gain an improved understanding of the inner workings of some of the most extreme explosions in the universe, so-called core-collapse supernovae/hypernovae and long gamma-ray bursts. To this end, we carried out new three-dimensional (3D) simulations of collapsing massive stars and studied the 3D dynamics of their collapsed cores.

 

Intellectual merit:

This project produced two major results:

(1) We demonstrated that 3D effects in rapidly spinning collapsing stellar cores prevent bipolar outflows ("jets") from forming. In previous simulations that assumed rotational symmetry of the star ("2D"), a clean energetic jet was found to emerge from the collapsed core. In 3D, the situation is more complicated and the extremely strong magnetic field in the core breaks up in a so-called screw-pinch-kink instability that also, as it turns out, play a role in magnetically confined fusion reactors. This result has implications for the connection of extreme core-collapse supernovae and long-gamma ray bursts. Our results suggest that the initial explosion may fail and a black hole may subsequently form and act as the central engine in some cases.

(2) Using 3D simulations with unprecedented resolution on NSF's Blue Waters supercomputer, we studied the growth of magnetic field in a newborn neutron star. Neutron stars are often also called pulsars or magnetars, because of the pulsed emission coming from a combination of magnetic field and rotation. Magnetars are neutron stars with extremely strong magnetic fields and it is presently not understood how such strong magnetic fields can be generated. Our simulations provide a clue: A newborn neutron star that is spinning rapidly and differentially (spinning faster at its core than at its surface), is unstable to the so-called "magnetorotational instability", which can convert differential rotation energy into magnetic field. For the first time, we were able to resolve this instability in a simulation. On top of that, we made a somewhat surprising discovery: there is a process active that converts small-scale magnetic field to an extremely strong globally-ordered magnetic field (as observed for magnetars). Such a process is called a "dynamo" and has long been hypothesized to operate. Our simulations for the first time showed that it does indeed operate! This result was published in Nature Magazine.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project involved a number of graduate students, undergraduates, and postdocs who were trained in carrying out and analyzing large-scale simulations and in writing the computer code necessary to run them. We disseminated our results to broad audiences via public lectures, participation in science podcasts, and our Simulating eXtreme Spacetimes YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/SXSCollaboration
